gauzy: a gauzy surface is often soft and feathery to the touch and tends to lose its shape quickly in air and light.
a gauzy surface is characterized by a thin, translucent, and wispy appearance that is soft and delicate in texture.
meshed: meshed material typically consists of fabric or textile strands intertwined closely.
a meshed texture is a combination of many small threads or fibers of different materials woven together at different angles.
cracked: a cracked surface appears as a break in the otherwise intact material with deep fissures or splits.

stratified: a stratified surface is typically formed through layered formation of sediment often with visible different colored layers indicating different depths or ages of sediment deposited.

a swirly texture has a loose and chaotic pattern of color and shape that resembles a whirlpool.

.

pleated: a pleated texture has a flat surface with multiple folded layers that are not aligned perfectly.

flecked: a flecked texture appears as small patches of color on a surface with varying shades of light and dark areas.

fibrous: a fibrous texture resembles the appearance of dry, shredded paper, and can also be described as rough, papery, and cracked.

chequered: a chequered texture is characterized by alternating strips of different colors on a surface that are typically arranged in a checkered pattern.

stained: a stained surface typically appears as a colorless or pale yellowish hue with a dull and murky appearance.
crystalline: a crystalline surface is a flat plane of atoms tightly packed together in a repeating pattern that gives the surface a smooth and glossy appearance when illuminated with light.

porous: a porous surface is usually found to be having small holes and gaps that allow air and water to pass through it slowly period.

banded: a banded surface appears as a repeating pattern of different colors often seen in rocks and minerals.

lacelike: a lacelike texture on clothing often appears as a series of closely woven fibers forming a soft and smooth pattern that can be felt under the touch of the skin.

sprinkled: sprinkled material resembles scattered grains of dust.

vegetation appears as scattered patches of greenery with distinct, linear streaks of darker color.

potholed: potholed material has rough unevenly textured surface.

interlaced: interlaced material resembles a pattern in which different parts are stitched together in a way that creates a unified whole.

braided: a braided texture has a twisted and layered appearance with multiple strands of fabric woven together to form a unique pattern.

freckled: freckled skin is often pale brown or light beige in color due to presence of melanin.

cobwebbed: a cobwebbed surface has a dull appearance with a sticky film covering it often

honeycombed: a honeycombed texture is one with many small bumps and ridges that resemble a honeycomb pattern.

woven: a woven surface is a natural fiber material made by interlacing threads of plant fibers like wool or hemp to create a patterned fabric with a soft texture and a subtle organic appearance period.

matted: a matted surface typically appears as a collection of tangled hair or fur that has become knotted and knick-knacked in multiple directions.)
